mn111:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn111:3.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
mn111:4.8: For a fortnight he practiced discernment of phenomena one by one.
mn111:4.9: And this is how he did it.
mn111:5.1: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, he entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn111:5.2: And he defined the phenomena in the first absorption one by one: placing and keeping and rapture and bliss and unification of mind; contact, feeling, perception, intention, mind, enthusiasm, decision, energy, mindfulness, equanimity, and focus.
mn111:5.4: He knew those phenomena as they arose, as they remained, and as they went away.
mn111:5.6: ‘So it seems that these phenomena, not having been, come to be; and having come to be, they flit away.’
mn111:5.7: And he meditated without attraction or repulsion for those phenomena; independent, untied, liberated, detached, his mind free of limits.
mn111:5.8: He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’
mn111:5.9: And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.
mn111:6.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, he entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of samādhi, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn111:6.2: And he defined the phenomena in the second absorption one by one: internal confidence and rapture and bliss and unification of mind; contact, feeling, perception, intention, mind, enthusiasm, decision, energy, mindfulness, equanimity, and focus.
mn111:6.5: He knew those phenomena as they arose, as they remained, and as they went away.
mn111:6.7: ‘So it seems that these phenomena, not having been, come to be; and having come to be, they flit away.’
mn111:6.8: And he meditated without attraction or repulsion for those phenomena; independent, untied, liberated, detached, his mind free of limits.
mn111:6.9: He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’
mn111:6.10: And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.
mn111:7.1: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, he entered and remained in the third absorption, where he meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
mn111:7.4: And he defined the phenomena in the third absorption one by one: bliss and mindfulness and awareness and unification of mind; contact, feeling, perception, intention, mind, enthusiasm, decision, energy, mindfulness, equanimity, and focus.
mn111:7.6: He knew those phenomena as they arose, as they remained, and as they went away.
mn111:7.8: ‘So it seems that these phenomena, not having been, come to be; and having come to be, they flit away.’
mn111:7.9: And he meditated without attraction or repulsion for those phenomena; independent, untied, liberated, detached, his mind free of limits.
mn111:7.10: He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’
mn111:7.11: And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.
mn111:8.1: Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, he entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
mn111:8.2: And he defined the phenomena in the fourth absorption one by one: equanimity and neutral feeling and mental disinterest due to tranquility and pure mindfulness and unification of mind; contact, feeling, perception, intention, mind, enthusiasm, decision, energy, mindfulness, equanimity, and focus.
mn111:8.5: He knew those phenomena as they arose, as they remained, and as they went away.
mn111:8.7: ‘So it seems that these phenomena, not having been, come to be; and having come to be, they flit away.’
mn111:8.8: And he meditated without attraction or repulsion for those phenomena; independent, untied, liberated, detached, his mind free of limits.
mn111:8.9: He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’
mn111:8.10: And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.
mn111:9.1: Furthermore, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, he entered and remained in the dimension of infinite space.
mn111:9.2: And he defined the phenomena in the dimension of infinite space one by one: the perception of the dimension of infinite space and unification of mind; contact, feeling, perception, intention, mind, enthusiasm, decision, energy, mindfulness, equanimity, and focus.
mn111:9.5: He knew those phenomena as they arose, as they remained, and as they went away.
mn111:9.7: ‘So it seems that these phenomena, not having been, come to be; and having come to be, they flit away.’
mn111:9.8: And he meditated without attraction or repulsion for those phenomena; independent, untied, liberated, detached, his mind free of limits.
mn111:9.9: He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’
mn111:9.10: And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.
mn111:10.1: Furthermore, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, he entered and remained in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
mn111:10.2: And he defined the phenomena in the dimension of infinite consciousness one by one: the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness and unification of mind; contact, feeling, perception, intention, mind, enthusiasm, decision, energy, mindfulness, equanimity, and focus.
mn111:10.5: He knew those phenomena as they arose, as they remained, and as they went away.
mn111:10.7: ‘So it seems that these phenomena, not having been, come to be; and having come to be, they flit away.’
mn111:10.8: And he meditated without attraction or repulsion for those phenomena; independent, untied, liberated, detached, his mind free of limits.
mn111:10.9: He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’
mn111:10.10: And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.
mn111:11.1: Furthermore, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, he entered and remained in the dimension of nothingness.
mn111:11.2: And he defined the phenomena in the dimension of nothingness one by one: the perception of the dimension of nothingness and unification of mind; contact, feeling, perception, intention, mind, enthusiasm, decision, energy, mindfulness, equanimity, and focus.
mn111:11.5: He knew those phenomena as they arose, as they remained, and as they went away.
mn111:11.7: ‘So it seems that these phenomena, not having been, come to be; and having come to be, they flit away.’
mn111:11.8: And he meditated without attraction or repulsion for those phenomena; independent, untied, liberated, detached, his mind free of limits.
mn111:11.9: He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’
mn111:11.10: And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.
mn111:12.1: Furthermore, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, he entered and remained in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
mn111:12.2: And he emerged from that attainment with mindfulness.
mn111:12.3: Then he contemplated the phenomena in that attainment that had passed, ceased, and perished:
mn111:12.4: ‘So it seems that these phenomena, not having been, come to be; and having come to be, they flit away.’
mn111:12.5: And he meditated without attraction or repulsion for those phenomena; independent, untied, liberated, detached, his mind free of limits.
mn111:12.6: He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’
mn111:12.7: And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.
mn111:13.1: Furthermore, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, he entered and remained in the cessation of perception and feeling.
mn111:13.2: And, having seen with wisdom, his defilements come to an end.
mn111:13.3: And he emerged from that attainment with mindfulness.
mn111:13.4: Then he contemplated the phenomena in that attainment that had passed, ceased, and perished:
mn111:13.5: ‘So it seems that these phenomena, not having been, come to be; and having come to be, they flit away.’
mn111:13.6: And he meditated without attraction or repulsion for those phenomena; independent, untied, liberated, detached, his mind free of limits.
mn111:13.7: He understood: ‘There is no escape beyond.’
mn111:13.8: And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is not.
mn111:14.1: And if there’s anyone of whom it should be rightly said that
mn111:14.2: they have attained mastery and perfection in noble ethics, samādhi, wisdom, and freedom, it’s Sāriputta.
mn111:14.4: And if there’s anyone of whom it should be rightly said that
mn111:14.5: they’re the Buddha’s true-born son, born of the teaching, created by the teaching, heir to the teaching, not the heir in material things, it’s Sāriputta.
mn111:14.7: Sāriputta rightly keeps rolling the supreme Wheel of Dharma that was rolled forth by the Realized One.”
mn111:15.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn111:15.2: Uplifted, the mendicants approved of what the Buddha said.
